semantic_title: Hurricane Aftermath - Sequencing of External Causes of Morbidity Codes and Priority Rules
section_path: Section I > A. Conventions > 19. Coding for Healthcare Encounters in Hurricane Aftermath > b. Sequencing of External Causes of Morbidity Codes

content.full_text: Codes for cataclysmic events, such as a hurricane, take priority over all other external cause codes except child and adult abuse and terrorism and should be sequenced before other external cause of injury codes. Assign as many external cause of morbidity codes as necessary to fully explain each cause. For example, if an injury occurs as a result of a building collapse during the hurricane, external cause codes for both the hurricane and the building collapse should be assigned, with the external causes code for hurricane being sequenced as the first external cause code. For injuries incurred as a direct result of the hurricane, assign the appropriate code(s) for the injuries, followed by the code X37.0-, Hurricane (with the appropriate 7th character), and any other applicable external cause of injury codes. Code X37.0- also should be assigned when an injury is incurred as a result of flooding caused by a levee breaking related to the hurricane. Code X38.-, Flood (with the appropriate 7th character), should be assigned when an injury is from flooding resulting directly from the storm. Code X36.0.-, Collapse of dam or man-made structure, should not be assigned when the cause of the collapse is due to the hurricane. Use of code X36.0- is limited to collapses of man-made structures due to earth surface movements, not due to storm surges directly from a hurricane. (Evidence: pg no: 18, L80-L83)
content.summary: Establishes priority sequencing rules for hurricane-related external cause codes and provides specific guidance for various hurricane-related injury scenarios (Evidence: pg no: 18, L80-L83)
key_concepts: Hurricane codes take priority over most external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 18, L80-L81)
Exceptions for abuse and terrorism codes (Evidence: pg no: 18, L80-L81)
Multiple external cause codes as necessary (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81)
Hurricane sequenced first among external causes (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81-L82)
Specific code assignments for different scenarios (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82-L83)
Restrictions on certain code usage (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82-L83)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Codes for cataclysmic events take priority over all other external cause codes except child and adult abuse and terrorism (Evidence: pg no: 18, L80-L81)
detailed_rules.explanation: Hurricane codes have priority in sequencing over most other external cause codes, with only abuse and terrorism codes taking higher priority (Evidence: pg no: 18, L80-L81)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Assign as many external cause of morbidity codes as necessary to fully explain each cause (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81)
detailed_rules.explanation: Multiple external cause codes should be used when necessary to completely describe all contributing factors to the injury (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code X37.0- should be assigned when an injury is incurred as a result of flooding caused by a levee breaking related to the hurricane (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82)
detailed_rules.explanation: Hurricane code X37.0- is appropriate for levee break flooding when the levee failure is related to the hurricane (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code X36.0- should not be assigned when the cause of the collapse is due to the hurricane (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82-L83)
detailed_rules.explanation: The collapse of dam or man-made structure code is limited to earth surface movements, not storm surges from hurricanes (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82-L83)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify all contributing external causes
Step 2: Determine if hurricane is involved
Step 3: Check for abuse or terrorism (higher priority)
Step 4: Sequence hurricane code first among external causes
Step 5: Add additional external cause codes as needed
Step 6: Apply specific code rules for flooding and collapse scenarios

specific_codes.description: Hurricane (with appropriate 7th character) (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82)
specific_codes.context: Direct hurricane injuries and levee break flooding

specific_codes.description: Flood (with appropriate 7th character) (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82)
Collapse of dam or man-made structure (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82-L83)
specific_codes.context: Limited to earth surface movements, not hurricane storm surges

coding_scenarios.scenario: Building collapse during hurricane causing injury
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient injured when building collapsed during Hurricane XYZ
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify injury from building collapse during hurricane
Step 3: Assign hurricane code X37.0- as first external cause
Step 4: Assign building collapse code as additional external cause

correct_coding.sequencing: Hurricane code sequenced before other external causes
correct_coding.rationale: Hurricane takes priority and should be sequenced first among external cause codes (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81-L82)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Hurricane code should be sequenced first among external causes
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Not prioritizing hurricane code in external cause sequencing

coding_scenarios.scenario: Injury from levee break flooding during hurricane
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient injured in flooding caused by levee failure during Hurricane XYZ
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify injury from levee break flooding
Step 2: Determine levee break related to hurricane
Step 4: Assign hurricane code X37.0- for levee break scenario

correct_coding.sequencing: Hurricane code appropriate for levee break flooding
correct_coding.rationale: Hurricane code should be assigned for levee break flooding related to hurricane (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should use hurricane code when levee break is hurricane-related
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using flood code instead of hurricane code for hurricane-related levee breaks

examples.code_example: Hurricane and building collapse codes both assigned

breakdown.Hurricane code: X37.0- sequenced first (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81-L82)
breakdown.Building collapse: Additional external cause code (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81-L82)
breakdown.Sequencing: Hurricane takes priority (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81-L82)

examples.rationale: Multiple external cause codes needed with hurricane taking priority in sequencing (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81-L82)

warnings: Do not use X36.0- for hurricane-caused structure collapse (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82-L83)
Hurricane codes take priority except for abuse and terrorism (Evidence: pg no: 18, L80-L81)
Use X37.0- for levee break flooding related to hurricane (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82)
best_practices: Assign multiple external cause codes as necessary (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81)
Sequence hurricane code first among external causes (Evidence: pg no: 18, L81-L82)
Use appropriate 7th characters for encounter type (Evidence: pg no: 18, L82)
common_mistakes: Not prioritizing hurricane codes in sequencing
Using structure collapse codes for hurricane-caused collapse
Missing additional external cause codes when multiple factors involved
tips: Hurricane codes have high priority in external cause sequencing
Multiple external causes may be needed for complete picture
Specific rules apply for flooding and structure collapse scenarios
implementation_notes: Priority rules help ensure consistent coding
Specific scenarios have detailed code assignment rules
clinical_context: Hurricane injuries often involve multiple contributing factors
Accurate external cause coding supports disaster response analysis
